articles.headline: With Uber’s I.P.O., Dara Khosrowshahi Is Taking Travis Kalanick’s Company Public
articles.snippet: The C.E.O. wants to prove that the start-up has evolved past a raucous, and profligate, tech-bro culture. But Uber’s past is simply not that far gone.
articles.abstract: The C.E.O. wants to prove that the start-up has evolved past a raucous, and profligate, tech-bro culture. But Uber’s past is simply not that far gone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dara Khosrowshahi had a problem. His name was Travis Kalanick.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Trump Says He Discussed the ‘Russian Hoax’ in a Phone Call With Putin
articles.snippet: The conversation took place shortly after the release of the special counsel’s report documenting Russian efforts to tilt the 2016 election in President Trump’s direction.
articles.abstract: The conversation took place shortly after the release of the special counsel’s report documenting Russian efforts to tilt the 2016 election in President Trump’s direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump telephoned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday for what both men described as a lengthy, positive conversation, in which they dismissed two years of investigations into Russia’s intervention in the 2016 presidential campaign as a “Russian Hoax” and a mountain that “ended up being a mouse.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler

articles.headline: How Do You Save a Million People From a Cyclone? Ask a Poor State in India
articles.snippet: Officials showed seasoned skill in evacuating a poor crowded area in Cyclone Fani’s path. “If you don’t learn from past experiences, you will drown,” one said.
articles.abstract: Officials showed seasoned skill in evacuating a poor crowded area in Cyclone Fani’s path. “If you don’t learn from past experiences, you will drown,” one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BHUBANESWAR, India — Flights were canceled.
articles.byline: By Hari Kumar, Jeffrey Gettleman and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: As Democrats Eye Flipping Senate, Top-Tier Candidates Decide to Pass
articles.snippet: Three high-profile potential candidates bowed out of running next year, following other top prospects who passed up Senate bids.
articles.abstract: Three high-profile potential candidates bowed out of running next year, following other top prospects who passed up Senate bids.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats, hungry for a sweep of power in Washington, are confronting a harsh reality: Top-tier candidates are refusing to run for the Senate.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Biden Thinks Trump Is the Problem, Not All Republicans. Other Democrats Disagree.
articles.snippet: The former vice president is defending his friendliness toward Republicans in Washington, saying Mr. Trump doesn’t represent them. But others say that view is naïve.
articles.abstract: The former vice president is defending his friendliness toward Republicans in Washington, saying Mr. Trump doesn’t represent them. But others say that view is naïve.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — As Joseph R. Biden Jr. made his way across Iowa on his first trip as a 2020 presidential candidate, the former vice president repeatedly returned to one term — aberration — when he referred to the Trump presidency.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Facebook Faces a Big Penalty, but Regulators Are Split Over How Big
articles.snippet: The F.T.C. chairman seems to have the votes to approve a settlement. One of the biggest issues has been whether to hold Mark Zuckerberg liable for future violations.
articles.abstract: The F.T.C. chairman seems to have the votes to approve a settlement. One of the biggest issues has been whether to hold Mark Zuckerberg liable for future violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facebook’s announcement in late April that it had set aside $3 billion to $5 billion to settle claims that it mishandled users’ personal data suggested a strong consensus by federal regulators that the social media giant needed to be held accountable.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Asked if a Woman Can Win, 2020 Candidates Offer an Easy Answer: ‘I Have’
articles.snippet: While the “must defeat Trump” calculus has largely buoyed male presidential candidates, several women in the Democratic field have a track record of winning over skeptical voters.
articles.abstract: While the “must defeat Trump” calculus has largely buoyed male presidential candidates, several women in the Democratic field have a track record of winning over skeptical voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRESTON, Iowa — Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York had a request: Before anyone mocked her claim that she was the Democratic presidential candidate best positioned to take on President Trump, at least listen to the evidence.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Shake-Up Looms at CBS News, as a Celebrated New Boss Makes Her Mark
articles.snippet: CBS News’s new president, Susan Zirinsky, is about to put her stamp on the network with a changed anchor lineup. Gayle King is expected to be the centerpiece of the network’s morning show.
articles.abstract: CBS News’s new president, Susan Zirinsky, is about to put her stamp on the network with a changed anchor lineup. Gayle King is expected to be the centerpiece of the network’s morning show.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Susan Zirinsky was named the new president of CBS’s troubled news division in January, she said she wanted to unite her team “both functionally and spiritually.”
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: After Intense Fighting in Gaza, Israel and Palestinians Observe Ceasefire
articles.snippet: The clash escalated into the worst fighting between Israel and Gaza since the 2014 war, killing four Israeli civilians and at least 22 Palestinians.
articles.abstract: The clash escalated into the worst fighting between Israel and Gaza since the 2014 war, killing four Israeli civilians and at least 22 Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Fighting between Israel and Gaza escalated rapidly on Sunday in the worst combat since the last full-blown war in 2014, with Palestinian rocket and missile attacks killing four Israeli civilians and Israeli forces taking aim at individual Gaza militants.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Trump Threatens China With More Tariffs Ahead of Final Trade Talks
articles.snippet: The president’s threat was aimed at forcing Beijing to agree to a final trade deal on America’s terms this week in Washington.
articles.abstract: The president’s threat was aimed at forcing Beijing to agree to a final trade deal on America’s terms this week in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, emboldened by a strong American economy and wary of criticism that an evolving trade deal with China would not adequately benefit the United States, threatened on Sunday to impose more punishing tariffs on Chinese goods in an attempt to force additional concessions in a final agreement.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Ride-Sharing’s Future? It May Sit on Electric Motorbikes
articles.snippet: In India, start-ups are opening a new front in the global ride-hailing battles, just as Uber prepares to go public.
articles.abstract: In India, start-ups are opening a new front in the global ride-hailing battles, just as Uber prepares to go public.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — In Uber’s vision of the future, self-driving cars will whisk us everywhere, eliminating the need for its millions of human drivers.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Trump Objects to Mueller Testifying Before Congress
articles.snippet: The stance put the president at odds with Democrats and his own attorney general, setting up another confrontation over presidential authority and the separation of powers.
articles.abstract: The stance put the president at odds with Democrats and his own attorney general, setting up another confrontation over presidential authority and the separation of powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump reversed himself on Sunday and said that the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, should not testify before Congress, setting up a potentially explosive confrontation with Democrats over presidential authority and the separation of powers.
articles.byline: By Michael Tackett and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Boeing Believed a 737 Max Warning Light Was Standard. It Wasn’t.
articles.snippet: Confusion inside Boeing about features related to a new software system underline the flawed design and rollout of the company’s troubled new jet.
articles.abstract: Confusion inside Boeing about features related to a new software system underline the flawed design and rollout of the company’s troubled new jet.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Boeing began delivering its 737 Max to customers in 2017, the company believed that a key cockpit warning light was a standard feature in all of the new jets.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Warren Buffett’s Case for Capitalism
articles.snippet: “I’m a card-carrying capitalist,” Warren Buffett said at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting. “I believe we wouldn’t be sitting here except for the market system.”
articles.abstract: “I’m a card-carrying capitalist,” Warren Buffett said at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting. “I believe we wouldn’t be sitting here except for the market system.”
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA — It is called “Woodstock for Capitalists” for a reason.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: In Tiger Woods, Trump Finds a Hero and a Business Opportunity
articles.snippet: The president has long cheered on Mr. Woods, who will receive the Medal of Freedom on Monday. But he has also cultivated the golfer as a celebrity who could add a sheen to his properties around the globe.
articles.abstract: The president has long cheered on Mr. Woods, who will receive the Medal of Freedom on Monday. But he has also cultivated the golfer as a celebrity who could add a sheen to his properties around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since Tiger Woods arrived on the public stage as a golf phenom at the age of 21, Donald J. Trump has been cultivating him as a celebrity who could add a sheen to his properties around the globe.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: Europe Is Reining In Tech Giants. But Some Say It’s Going Too Far.
articles.snippet: Bids to block harmful and violent content online in Europe are drawing criticism for limiting free expression and undercutting the ideals of an open web.
articles.abstract: Bids to block harmful and violent content online in Europe are drawing criticism for limiting free expression and undercutting the ideals of an open web.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Spain, activists were convicted for social media posts that violated an expanded antiterrorism law. The Twitter accounts of German citizens were blocked because of rules enacted last year that prohibit hate speech. And a Dutch court determined Google must remove search results about a doctor punished for poor performance, in compliance with a privacy law.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: CBS Names Norah O’Donnell as Lead Anchor, Signaling a New Era
articles.snippet: The new CBS News chief, Susan Zirinsky, announces a fresh start after workplace misconduct scandals involving Charlie Rose, Jeff Fager and Leslie Moonves.
articles.abstract: The new CBS News chief, Susan Zirinsky, announces a fresh start after workplace misconduct scandals involving Charlie Rose, Jeff Fager and Leslie Moonves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like any family reunion, the gathering inside CBS News on Monday had joys and tensions alike.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Gives Birth to a Boy
articles.snippet: The newborn, the first multiracial baby in the monarchy’s recent history, is seventh in line to the British throne behind his father, Prince Harry.
articles.abstract: The newborn, the first multiracial baby in the monarchy’s recent history, is seventh in line to the British throne behind his father, Prince Harry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry could barely contain himself. Facing a news camera to announce his son’s birth, he rubbed his hands together, bounced on the balls of his feet and seemed unable to stop himself from grinning, even for a second.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Palko Karasz

articles.headline: Democrats Threaten to Hold Barr in Contempt as White House Guards Tax Returns
articles.snippet: A showdown between the executive and legislative branches has ratcheted up, as President Trump and his administration have resisted Democrats’ oversight efforts on multiple fronts.
articles.abstract: A showdown between the executive and legislative branches has ratcheted up, as President Trump and his administration have resisted Democrats’ oversight efforts on multiple fronts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration ruled out turning over President Trump’s tax returns to the House on Monday and girded for a looming contempt of Congress resolution against Attorney General William P. Barr.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: New Tensions With Iran Threaten Nuclear Deal and, White House Says, U.S. Troops
articles.snippet: The mutual threats escalated action from both the U.S., which warned against attacks, and Iran, which said it would not fully comply with a deal President Trump already abandoned.
articles.abstract: The mutual threats escalated action from both the U.S., which warned against attacks, and Iran, which said it would not fully comply with a deal President Trump already abandoned.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tensions escalated between the United States and Iran on Monday as the Trump administration accused Iran and militias that it backs of threatening American troops, and Iran signaled it might soon violate part of the 2015 nuclear deal it reached under former President Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Six Years Ago, He Helped Expose VW’s Diesel Fraud. This Year, G.M. Let Him Go.
articles.snippet: Hemanth Kappanna’s research helped plunge Volkswagen into a scandal that continues to plague it. In February, he got two months’ pay and a one-way ticket to India.
articles.abstract: Hemanth Kappanna’s research helped plunge Volkswagen into a scandal that continues to plague it. In February, he got two months’ pay and a one-way ticket to India.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Hemanth Kappanna might seem like just another victim of corporate restructuring, a foreign worker whose skills were no longer needed, a middle-aged man with dashed American dreams.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing
